title_sort: reuben farwell to walt whitman, 2 october 1864
title: Reuben Farwell to Walt Whitman, 2 October 1864
text: Plymouth Mich.At HomeOct 2d/64Dear Comrad[Comrade]Yours I recived[received] several weeks ago. Though I have been quite unwell like your self This makes the fourth week I have been out of the Service of Uncle Sam I hardly know what to write you at present because I do not know wether[whether] you ever will recive[receive] it or not. I am some better than I was when I arrived hereI trust that you will excuse me in not writing you beforeThough I tried to find out by the Boys in Armory where you were But they could not tellNow Uncle if you will (not) Answer this after My being detained in geting[getting] yours from the Regt. I belonged to too this placeI least I hope you will Try and give me a ReplyI trust that this may find you well and in better health than when you wrote me last. I will answer All enquireys[enquiries] from you. this from one who would like to see you IndeedA Comrad[Comrade]Ruben Farwell Reuben Farwell to Walt Whitman, 2 October 1864
